titleStmt.title: The Snake in the Cistern Harran

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: One day, long time ago, someone was walking along the way. When he passed by a cistern, he heard a cry—a voice from below shouting, “Help! Help me! I need assistance!”

Someone was in need of help. The man realized it was the voice of a snake which spoke (to him)—a large snake trapped inside of the cistern, being stuck in the water. The snake was unable to get out of the cistern.

The man turned to the snake and looked at it. It started speaking to him by God’s will. He asked, “What do you want from me, o snake?” It replied, “O human, please save me from the water! Extend your hand to help me out; I cannot do it alone. I am on the verge of dying.”

He replied, “Alright, but you are a snake, and I fear that if I extend my hand, you will bite me.” The snake said, “Trust in God. Don’t be afraid! If you take me out of the water you will do me a great kindness. How could I repay such a favour by killing, biting, or stinging you?”

He said, “Alright! I place my trust in God.” He extended his hand to it and pulled the snake out of the cistern. Once he had rescued it from the cistern, (the snake) said, “I want to give you a piece of advice. As you have done me such a great kindness, I wish to offer you this advice.”

The snake advised him, “Never trust a human who drinks raw milk!” Humans, after all, are consumers of raw milk; aren’t we suckled with raw milk? We humans suckle raw milk (from other mothers). In Turkish, they say ‘unboiled milk’. Never trust someone who drinks raw milk. Don’t trust him. Don’t believe him!”

He said, “Is this the advice?” It replied, “Yes, but I strongly advise you: Don’t trust any human who drinks raw milk!” He said, “Alright!” Then he went out into the open field, heading somewhere. While he was on his way, a lion suddenly appeared in front of him.

The lion met him on his path. The lion had just caught someone, a man, and had eaten him. This man had gold, he had a bag of gold with him. The lion said, “Hey you!" I (have eaten) the man, I am full, now I am full.” This is what the lion said.

The lion said, “Hey, I have eaten the man’s flesh, but the gold remains. I don’t eat gold; it’s just metal, tin. Take this bag of gold, for you are a human and you need it. Take it and go, let it be yours!”

He said, “By God, dude, aren’t you going to eat me?” The lion replied, “God is your guarantor; don’t be afraid of me!” He took the bag of gold from the lion and left. After he had taken it from the lion he returned to the town, let’s say he returned to Urfa, to the city.

He came to the city. When he arrived to the city, he went to a friend of his, one from the town. When came he he saw his friend and said, “Come, let's go to a restaurant to eat bread! Let's have lunch!”

They came to the restaurant and were eating the food. When it was time to pay, to give the money for the meal, he said to his friend, “Wait! I have gold, I will pay. You don’t need to pay for the food.”

He said, “What do you have?” The man replied, “Stop!” When he opened the bag, the mouth of the bag, (he saw that) it was filled with gold. When his friend saw the gold, he was stunned. (The man) got up and gave the (guy from the) restaurant a gold coin or a piece of gold.

He closed the bag and threw it over his shoulder. His friend, his true friend, said, “Man, you have so much gold, give me some of it!” The man replied, “Why should I give you any? I have already paid for your lunch and you are my friend.”

So he said, “Alright! You won’t give me any?” The man replied, “No!” He said, “Okay, don’t give me any!” Then (his friend) went away and reported him to the authorities saying, “So-and-so has a bag of gold, and I don’t know where he got it from. Perhaps he has robbed it from somewhere. Come and arrest him!”

They came and arrested him; the authorities took him and put him in prison. They imprisoned him in the lower part (of the prison). The one who imprisoned him was the judge. Or, at that time, let’s say it was the governor who locked him up in the basement.

He imprisoned him. The governor had a son, about eighteen or twenty years old, living at home, sitting on a place. Suddenly, the snake, the same one that was his friend before, came to the governor’s son. It wrapped itself around his legs, it entwined him and stopped while his his face was like that.

It has wrapped itself around the governor’s son, and it was large. It stood there, not allowing anyone to come close; wrapped around the son of the governor. As they approached, the snake warned them, saying: “Do not come closer, or I will kill him.”

No one dared to approach the snake. Meanwhile, the man was still in prison, in arrest. The governor’s men were talking, saying that the governor's son was wrapped by a snake which threatened to kill him.
No one dared to approach her because it was a viper. The man, who was in prison, said to them, “Go and tell the governor that if he permits me to leave the dungeon, I will go and save his son.”

The news quickly reached the governor. They went to the governor and said to him, “The one you have imprisoned, the one whose gold bag you took, says that if you release him from prison, he will come and save your son.”

He said, “Anyway, my son is about to die and no one can save him. Let him come and let’s see!" When he came, the snake looked at him and said, “O you, when you freed me from the cistern, didn’t I tell you not to trust any human who drinks raw milk?”

He said, “By God! Yes, you told me!” It replied, “Yes, look! I have come to save you. I have seized his son to save you.” The governor was listening. Then he said to the governor, “If I save your son, will you give me my gold back? And also give me a letter that says that you will not harm me any longer? Will you give me a letter stating that you will not trouble me?”

He said, “I will put my seal on it and I will give it to you. And I will give you your gold.” After he had given him the gold, (the man) said to the snake, “Go down!” He brought a bag, placed it in it, and then...
After he had saved (the snake) and had taken it out, it said, “I told you, the person who drinks raw milk, do not trust him!” Enjoy it!
